Navigation
Name Rascal/Expressions/Values/List
Synopsis List values.
Syntax [ Exp1, Exp2, ... ]
Types
Exp1 Exp2 ... [ Exp1, Exp2, ... ]
T1 T2 ... list[lub(T1, T2, ... )]
Usage import List; (included in Prelude)
Details Append Comprehension Concatenation Difference Equal in Insert Intersection NotEqual notin Product StrictSubList StrictSuperList SubList Subscription SuperList
Description A list is an ordered sequence of values and has the following properties:
  • All elements have the same static type.
  • The order of the elements matters.
  • A list may contain an element more than once.
The type of a list has the form list[T], where T is an arbitrary type.

When variables of type list occur inside a list, their elements are automatically spliced into the surrounding set. This can be prevented by surrounding them with extra [ and ] brackets. Note that this approach is atypical: in Rascal splicing is implicit while in other languages it has to be indicated explicitly by the programmer.

The following functions and operators on lists are provided:

  • Append: Append an element at the end of a list
  • Comprehension: A list comprehension generates a list value.
  • Concatenation: Concatenate two lists.
  • Difference: The difference between two lists.
  • Equal: Equality on lists.
  • in: Membership test on list elements.
  • Insert: add an element in front of a list
  • Intersection: Intersection of two lists.
  • NotEqual: Not equal operator on lists.
  • notin: Negated membership test on lists.
  • Product: Compute the product of two lists.
  • StrictSubList: The strict sublist operator on lists.
  • StrictSuperList: The strict super list operator on lists.
  • SubList: The sublist operator on lists.
  • Subscription: Retrieve a list element via its index.
  • SuperList: The super list operator on lists.
Examples 
rascal>[1, 2, 3];
list[int]: [1,2,3]
rascal>[<1,10>, <2,20>, <3,30>];
list[tuple[int,int]]: [
  <1,10>,
  <2,20>,
  <3,30>
]
rascal>[1, "b", 3];
list[value]: [1,"b",3]
rascal>[<"a",10>, <"b",20>, <"c",30>];
list[tuple[str,int]]: [
  <"a",10>,
  <"b",20>,
  <"c",30>
]
rascal>[["a", "b"], ["c", "d", "e"]];
list[list[str]]: [
  ["a","b"],
  ["c","d","e"]
]
List splicing works as follows: 
rascal>L = [1, 2, 3];
list[int]: [1,2,3]
rascal>[10, L, 20];
list[value]: [
  10,
  [1,2,3],
  20
]
rascal>[10, [L], 20];
list[value]: [
  10,
  [[1,2,3]],
  20
]

Questions
Question [1]. The type of a list is determined by:




Question [2]. Complete this function that tests that a list of words forms a palindrome. A palindrome is a word that is symmetrical
Fill in 
import List;
public bool isPalindrome(list[str] words){
  return words == ;
}
and make the following true:
isPalindrome(["a", "b", "b", "a"]) == true;
